landlord_tenant_relationship.reasoning: Complaint pleads a written lease (¶4), plaintiff’s possession of the studio (¶2, ¶6, ¶24), payment of monthly rent (¶4), and identifies defendant as landlord/owner (¶3) — facts establishing a landlord-tenant relationship.

act_or_omission_by_landlord.reasoning: Complaint alleges specific landlord conduct and omissions: misrepresentation that the leak was “totally fixed” (¶8, ¶26(a)), repeated failures to timely/adequately repair water intrusion and remediate mold (¶10–11, ¶12–13, ¶26(b)–(c)), and dismissive statements treating the problem as “cosmetic” (¶11, ¶26(d)).

substantial_interference.reasoning: Plead facts show more than minor inconvenience: recurring water intrusion soaking furniture and ruining a laptop (¶9, ¶12), persistent musty smell and suspected mold (¶13), plaintiff’s health symptoms and relocation of her bed and avoidance of half the apartment (¶14), and explicit allegation that use and enjoyment were substantially interfered with (¶15, ¶26(e)).

causation.reasoning: Complaint connects the landlord’s representations and failures to act with the harmful condition and harms: stains observed before lease and leak recurring in same location (¶7–9), tenant’s timely notice and repeated complaints (¶10), landlord’s failure to repair/remediate (¶11, ¶26(b)–(c)), and resulting property damage, loss of use, and health effects (¶12–14, ¶27) — adequately alleging proximate causation.

damages.reasoning: Complaint alleges specific economic damages (ruined laptop ≈ $900 ¶12, prayer ¶A(i)), loss of full use of the apartment and relocation of bed (¶14, ¶27), emotional distress and inconvenience (¶14, ¶27), and an additional estimated $1,000 in compensatory damages (¶16, ¶27) — adequately pleading damages.
